articles.headline: Appeals Courts Pushed to Right by Bush Choices
articles.snippet: By appointing younger and more conservative judges, the administration has transformed federal appeals courts.
articles.abstract: By appointing younger and more conservative judges, the administration has transformed federal appeals courts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a group of doctors challenged a South Dakota law forcing them to inform women that abortions “terminate the life of a whole, separate, unique living human being” — using exactly that language — President Bush’s appointees to the federal appeals courts took control.

articles.headline: Panicked Traders Take VW Shares on a Wild Ride
articles.snippet: Regulators are examining a torrent of panicky trading in Volkswagen shares that at one point Tuesday turned VW into the world’s most valuable company.
articles.abstract: Regulators are examining a torrent of panicky trading in Volkswagen shares that at one point Tuesday turned VW into the world’s most valuable company.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Louise Story, Michael J. de la Merced and Carter Dougherty.
articles.byline: By Louise Story, Michael J. de la Merced and Carter Dougherty

articles.headline: Consumers Feel the Next Crisis: It’s Credit Cards
articles.snippet: After years of flooding Americans with offers and high limits for credit cards, lenders are cutting back sharply on both.
articles.abstract: After years of flooding Americans with offers and high limits for credit cards, lenders are cutting back sharply on both.
articles.lead_paragraph: First came the mortgage crisis. Now comes the credit card crisis.

articles.headline: Mourning Old Media’s Decline
articles.snippet: The paradox is that the print media do not have an audience problem, but a consumer problem.
articles.abstract: The paradox is that the print media do not have an audience problem, but a consumer problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news that Google settled two longstanding suits with book authors and publishers over its plans to digitize the world’s great libraries suggests that some level of détente could be reached between old media and new.

articles.headline: Sense of Unease in Some Black Voters
articles.snippet: Many black voters in Florida are worried that their votes will not be counted and an Obama victory will slip away.
articles.abstract: Many black voters in Florida are worried that their votes will not be counted and an Obama victory will slip away.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  For weeks now, James Jones has been extra courteous in traffic and at the gas station because he has an Obama sticker on the back of his truck. “Something like that might make a difference for Barack Obama,” Mr. Jones explained. “I’m not taking a chance.”

articles.headline: Are Stocks the Bargain You Think?
articles.snippet: The bears, who say that stocks are overvalued long term, do have a valid argument. Based on numbers and history, it has at least as much claim on reason as the bullish argument does.
articles.abstract: The bears, who say that stocks are overvalued long term, do have a valid argument. Based on numbers and history, it has at least as much claim on reason as the bullish argument does.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s most famous investors, including Warren Buffett and John Bogle, have started to make the case that it’s time to dive back into the stock market.

articles.headline: Reserve Fund’s Investors Still Await Their Cash
articles.snippet: At least 400,000 people, and perhaps as many as a million, can’t access their savings in the Reserve Fund, the nation’s oldest money market fund, with no sure end in sight.
articles.abstract: At least 400,000 people, and perhaps as many as a million, can’t access their savings in the Reserve Fund, the nation’s oldest money market fund, with no sure end in sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The national “bank holiday” that ushered in the New Deal in 1933 locked up the public’s cash for four days. The crisis that hit last month at the Reserve Fund, the nation’s oldest money market fund, has frozen hundreds of thousands of customer accounts for more than six weeks  with no sure end in sight.
